Legal_Issue: Can damages for trespass continue to accrue after the issuance of a statement of claim?
Application_Facts: The Kincolith Band used Marlon Watts' land without permission from 1985; appraisal valued rent at $725/year; trespass continued past the 1996 statement of claim
Decision_Outcome: Damages are limited to the period before the statement of claim
Remedy_Requested: Damages for unauthorized use of land
Court_Ruling: Plaintiff awarded $10,300 for 1985–1996, plus costs and interest; future claims require new action
Defendant_Behavior: Unauthorized use of plaintiff's land for communication equipment
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized occupation and use of private land
Legal_Standard: Damages can only be awarded for losses accrued before commencement of action
Procedural_Issue: Default judgment granted in 1999 due to non-contestation by defendants
Application_Basis: Legal precedent limiting damages to pre-claim period
Governing_Rule: Under common law, damages cannot extend beyond the date of the statement of claim without specific statutory authority
Outcome: Plaintiff received $10,300 in damages, $5,281.95 in costs, and interest
Harm_Assessment: Financial loss due to unauthorized use of land at $725/year
Cause_Description: Unauthorized use of plaintiff's land by the Kincolith Band for communication equipment
Evidence_Handling: Reference hearing held to determine damages
Evidence_Assessment: Appraisal accepted as basis for annual rental value
Decision_Rationale: Damages cut off at date of statement of claim per common law precedent
Decision_Making_Body: Court granting default judgment and reference hearing panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Common law rule on accrual of damages in trespass actions
